reviews.review:
I can recommend this game if you want to be called dick or a n****. The community is so extremely toxic, I have no idea why they would allow a chat box at the end of a match as it offers nothing to the game. If it's for commendations, just implement a system where people can thumbs up other players. 

Seriously this community is so toxic it ruins the game completely. I'm disappointed I wasted my time and money on it. Not to mention the entire game is filled with hackers, but nobody does anything because the hackers are usually survivors and 3 people aren't going to rat out the one who is helping them win.

Killers are so heavily gimped in the game, survivors can loop certain killers forever due to terrible map design. Other killers are practically useless so you're stuck using a certain amount of killers and ignoring the rest.

Don't buy!
Great atmosphere - does take a bit of getting used to but an easy enough game to grasp
Its a great game but can be a little scary time to time

Dead by daylight is a thrilling and fun game to play. With friend and solo. Playing the game is worth its while for sure. The gameplay is mostly smooth as the content creaters do their best to fix bugs. I would highly recommend the game just to try it. U won't regret it ofc :)
To the content creators, I'd like to see a daily calender such as the one in the mobile version of the game.

BHVR seems to never be able to fix their game in one aspect without ruining it in another. With every patch 1000 new bugs appear and 5 are fixed. The only reason their game is thriving is due to them having a strong grip on the genre DBD falls under and having a lot of popular horror licenses.

The Brief Version: A hide and seek horror-themed game limited by major contradictions to its core design and a number of paywalls to play especially competitively.  Three out of five stars; buy it on sale if you like the concept.

The Long Version:

Dead by Daylight is a game where four weaker and mostly slower survivors have to successfully find a way to both not get murdered and repair five generators distributed throughout the map to escape the ostensibly faster and stronger killer.  The levels features lockers to hide in, wooden pallets you can drop on the killer or vault over, or windows you can also vault through to gain some distance as the killer generally vaults through them more slowly than survivors do.  As for the killer, their goal is to sacrifice all four survivors.  By default, the killer must hit a survivor twice to down them, and then pick them up and hook them.  Once on the hook, if they are not rescued or manage to free themselves (risky and unlikely by default), the Entity will eventually kill them after a timer runs out, removing them from the match.  If rescued, a survivor can potentially be hooked and freed once more, depending on how long it took to rescue them.  Effectively, this amounts to a sort of "three strikes and you're out" mechanic.  I personally found this core gameplay to be quite fun, promoting a sort of guessing game between the survivors and killers; I'd give the game a 4.25 out of 5 if it were only this, but unfortunately this is not the case.

The game's loadout system is where most of the problems come in.  Now the idea to be able to build strengths around a certain playstyle isn't bad in and of itself, but the actual items, perks, add-ons and offerings available are often downright cheesy and flout the aforementioned core concept, as do a number of killer powers (survivors only have perks).  There are actually quite a few that are contradictory to the basic gameplay, but for brevity's sake I will only give a few that hopefully illustrate the problem.

-Example Iffy Perks: BBQ & Chili (Killer), Dark Sense (Survivor), Decisive Strike (Survivor)-
BBQ and Chili: A killer perk so good (and usually behind a pay wall) that there is essentially no reason *not* to use it if you have it.  It gives you up to 100% extra bloodpoints each time you hook a survivor (the in game equivalent of spendable experience points) and, eschewing the "hide and seek" archetype, literally just outlines any survivors more than 40 meters away from you for four seconds.
Dark Sense: A survivor perk which outlines the killer for 5 seconds each time a generator is completed, and 10 seconds when 5 generators have been completed.  Killers usually already have a "terror radius" of 20-32 meters, which amounts to a heartbeat sound playing for the survivors regardless of whether they have vision or not.  Though this can cut both ways, it allows survivors using it to essentially know for free if they can just mindlessly go to the next closest gen, or if they ought to hide, without ever seeing or hearing the killer coming their way.  This similarly flies in the face of the basic concept.
Decisive Strike: Usually behind a paywall, this survivor perk allows any survivor equipped with it to instantly break free from a killer and stun them for five seconds after they've been picked up by them by pressing the space bar at the right time, so long as the survivor has been unhooked or escaped from the hook within the last minute of play.  As the killer first has to track down and hit said survivor if they aren't camping the hook, what this usually effectively amounts to is flagrantly bold play by survivors who have it equipped, typically either trying their best to interfere or taunt the killer or literally ignoring them while their "get out of jail free" card is available.  So much for being "unstoppable" and "terrifying!"

-Example Iffy Offering: Ebony Memento Mori-
The Ebony Memento Mori is in and of itself not a terrible idea, as it allows the killer to literally just murder the survivors instead of hooking them.  Where it goes wrong is that unlike normal rules, where a survivor has to be hooked thrice to die when rescued in a timely manner, is that the killer can just skip all that and kill you if you've even been hooked once, regardless if you had reached the struggle phase already or not.  This arbitrarily shortens the game, allowing a killer who simply wants to "win" to basically cheat the "three strikes and you're out" rule of the default game.

-Example Iffy Killer Power: Evil Within (Mike Myers/The Shape)-
Myers is a paywall killer with a power related to "stalking" the survivors.  Seems relevant and a good idea up to that point, but the implementation is not great.  Essentially he gathers evil points by holding a button while survivors are in view.  Once these points reach certain thresholds, his power adds passive bonuses, increasing his speed and mobility to normal levels at stage two.  Unfortunately at stage three, he surpasses the normal strength of "average" killers immensely for a full minute or more depending on his loadout, where he moves faster, vaults faster, has a longer lunge, and *always* downs any hit survivors with one hit instead of the normal two.  As the survivors normally get a short but significant speed boost after being hit and consequently something of a chance to make a good move to get away, this killer's power ignores the game's core design.

-Example Iffy Add-ons: Brand New Part, Iridescent Heads-
The Brand New Part allows a survivor to greatly reduce the time it takes to repair a generator relative to normal, greatly enhancing "gen rush" tactics where the average killer simply cannot cover enough ground to protect the objectives they're supposed to.  This allows survivors who use it (especially if everyone equips it) to more or less skip the stealth side of the game by shortening the default game time significantly.
The Iridescent Heads are a killer add-on for "The Huntress."  I play her often and enjoy her despite her lower than normal speed and consequent weakness to "looping" on certain maps, but this add-on is notable in that if you land a hatchet throw, it will also instantly down the survivor rather than following the normal rule of having to hit a survivor twice.  Again, this change deprives survivors of the normal chance to counterplay against the killer by skipping the injured speed boost.

As mentioned earlier, these are sadly only a few of the options that allow players to more or less say "screw the rules, I have bloodpoints/auric cells", and to bludgeon the basic game and players who do not have them with what more or less amount to crutches.  Further compounding this issue is the horrendous matchmaking system, which frequently results in players who have many hundreds or even thousands of hours under their belt being placed with people that only have 50.  Additionally, a significant number of the player base are pretty rude or even toxic, but it appears Behaviour does not seem to care.  For instance, some killer players will "facecamp" survivors, literally never abandoning the hook after they've gotten someone on it, giving them no chance to rejoin the match, with no substantial penalty to the killer doing so.  Many survivor players will also troll what are usually newer killers by taking advantage of various "meta" quirks and flaws of the game and try to antagonize them in-game and in the post-game chat.  There are nice players too, but most people remember the negative ones.  Needless to say, this generally disappointing reality seriously degrades what could be a really great game of its genre into an average-at-best one.  I do not intend on spending anymore than what little I have already for that reason, and recommend that anyone considering purchasing it should go skimming around the community and the like so that they really understand what they're getting into before they spend their money on it.
